tasks: Automatic Continuity of Positive Matrix and Operator Semigroups
title: Automatic Time Continuity of Positive Matrix and Operator Semigroups.pdf
abstract: . We consider a matrix semigroup T : [0, ∞) →Rd×d without as- suming any measurability properties and show that, if T is bounded close to 0 and T(t) ≥0 entrywise for all t, then T is continuous. This complements classical results for the scalar-valued case. We also prove an analogous result if T takes values in the positive operators over a sequence space. 1. Introduction Motivation. It is a classical theme of ideas that a function T : [0, ∞) →R that satisﬁes the functional equation T (0) = 1, T (t + s) = T (t)T (s) for all s, t ∈[0, ∞) (1.1) is, under mild conditions, given by T (t) = eta for a number a ∈R and all t ∈[0, ∞). For instance, this is true if T is continuous at 0. Alternatively, it suﬃces to assume that T is measurable and is not constantly zero on (0, ∞). We refer to [6, Sections I.1 and VII.2] for a more thorough discussion of this theme of ideas. In a similar vein, the following result holds, where measurability is replaced with a boundedness assumption close to 0. Proposition 1.1 (Continuity of scalar semigroups). Let T : [0, ∞) →R satisfy the functional equation (1.1) and assume that T (t) ̸= 0 for at least one t ∈(0, ∞). If supt∈[0,1] |T (t)| < ∞, then T is continuous (and hence T (t) = eta for a number a ∈R and all t ∈[0, ∞)). This observation motivates the theorems in the following sections, and we also use it in an argument below. In order to be more self-contained, we thus include a proof of the continuity of T in Proposition 1.1 at the end of the introduction. Note that Proposition 1.1 does not remain true if T maps to C instead of R, see the simple Example 1.2 below. By identifying each complex number with an orthogonal matrix in R2×2 we can thus see that the proposition does not hold for matrix-valued functions T , either. In this note we show that the proposition remains valid, though, if T is matrix- valued and satisﬁes T (t) ≥0 entrywise for each t ∈[0, ∞) (Theorem 2.1). More generally, a similar result remains true if each T (t) is a positive linear operator on a sequence space (Theorem 3.1 and Corollary 3.2). Matrix and operator semigroups. We use the following notation. For a Banach space E, let L(E) denote the space of bounded linear operators on E. If E = Rn, we identify L(E) with the matrix space Rn×n in the usual way.
